trans-unit.source: Reliable Actors design pattern: resource governance
trans-unit.target: Reliable Actors design pattern: resource governance

trans-unit.source: This pattern and related scenarios are easily recognizable by developers—enterprise or otherwise—who have constrained resources on-premises or in the cloud, which they cannot immediately scale or that wish to ship large scale applications and data to the cloud.
trans-unit.target: This pattern and related scenarios are easily recognizable by developers—enterprise or otherwise—who have constrained resources on-premises or in the cloud, which they cannot immediately scale or that wish to ship large scale applications and data to the cloud.

trans-unit.source: In the enterprise these constrained resources, such as databases, run on scale-up hardware.
trans-unit.target: In the enterprise these constrained resources, such as databases, run on scale-up hardware.

trans-unit.source: Anyone with a long enterprise history knows this is a common situation on-premises.
trans-unit.target: Anyone with a long enterprise history knows this is a common situation on-premises.

trans-unit.source: Even at cloud scale, we have seen this situation occur when a cloud service has attempted to exceed the 64K TCP limit of connections between an address/port tuple, or when attempting to connect to a cloud-based database that limits the number of concurrent connections.
trans-unit.target: Even at cloud scale, we have seen this situation occur when a cloud service has attempted to exceed the 64K TCP limit of connections between an address/port tuple, or when attempting to connect to a cloud-based database that limits the number of concurrent connections.

trans-unit.source: Typically in the past, this was solved by throttling through message-based middleware or by custom-built pooling and façade mechanisms.
trans-unit.target: Typically in the past, this was solved by throttling through message-based middleware or by custom-built pooling and façade mechanisms.

trans-unit.source: These are hard to get right, especially when we need to scale the middle tier but still maintain the correct connection counts.
trans-unit.target: These are hard to get right, especially when we need to scale the middle tier but still maintain the correct connection counts.

trans-unit.source: It’s just fragile and complex.
trans-unit.target: It’s just fragile and complex.

trans-unit.source: In fact, like the Smart Cache pattern, this pattern spans across multiple scenarios and customers who already have working systems with constrained resources.
trans-unit.target: In fact, like the Smart Cache pattern, this pattern spans across multiple scenarios and customers who already have working systems with constrained resources.

trans-unit.source: They are building systems where they need to scale-out not just the services, but their state in-memory as well as the persisted state in stable storage.
trans-unit.target: They are building systems where they need to scale-out not just the services, but their state in-memory as well as the persisted state in stable storage.

trans-unit.target: Modeling cache scenarios with actors

trans-unit.source: Essentially we model access to resources as an actor or multiple actors that act as proxies (say connection, for example) to a resource or a group of resources.
trans-unit.target: Essentially we model access to resources as an actor or multiple actors that act as proxies (say connection, for example) to a resource or a group of resources.

trans-unit.source: You can then either directly manage the resource through individual actors or use a coordination actor that manages the resource actors.
trans-unit.target: You can then either directly manage the resource through individual actors or use a coordination actor that manages the resource actors.

trans-unit.source: To make this more concrete, we will address the common need of having to work against a partitioned (aka sharded) storage tier for performance and scalability reasons.
trans-unit.target: To make this more concrete, we will address the common need of having to work against a partitioned (aka sharded) storage tier for performance and scalability reasons.

trans-unit.source: Our first option is pretty basic: we can use a static function to map and resolve our actors to downstream resources.
trans-unit.target: Our first option is pretty basic: we can use a static function to map and resolve our actors to downstream resources.

trans-unit.source: Such a function can return, for example, a connection string with given input.
trans-unit.target: Such a function can return, for example, a connection string with given input.

trans-unit.source: It is entirely up to us how to implement that function.
trans-unit.target: It is entirely up to us how to implement that function.

trans-unit.source: Of course, this approach comes with its own drawbacks such as static affinity that makes repartitioning resources or remapping an actor to resources very difficult.
trans-unit.target: Of course, this approach comes with its own drawbacks such as static affinity that makes repartitioning resources or remapping an actor to resources very difficult.

trans-unit.source: First, we model the affinity between physical resources and actors.
trans-unit.target: First, we model the affinity between physical resources and actors.

trans-unit.source: This is done through an actor called Resolver that understands the mapping between users, logical partitions, and physical resources.
trans-unit.target: This is done through an actor called Resolver that understands the mapping between users, logical partitions, and physical resources.

trans-unit.source: Resolver maintains its data in a persisted store, however it is cached for easy lookup.
trans-unit.target: Resolver maintains its data in a persisted store, however it is cached for easy lookup.

trans-unit.source: As we saw in the Exchange Rate sample earlier in the Smart Cache pattern, Resolver can proactively fetch the latest information using a timer.
trans-unit.target: As we saw in the Exchange Rate sample earlier in the Smart Cache pattern, Resolver can proactively fetch the latest information using a timer.

trans-unit.source: Once the user actor resolves the resource it needs to use, it caches it in a local variable called _resolution and uses it during its lifetime.
trans-unit.target: Once the user actor resolves the resource it needs to use, it caches it in a local variable called _resolution and uses it during its lifetime.

trans-unit.source: We chose a look-up based resolution (illustrated below) over simple hashing or range hashing because of the flexibility it provides in operations such as scaling in/out or moving a user from one resource to another.
trans-unit.target: We chose a look-up based resolution (illustrated below) over simple hashing or range hashing because of the flexibility it provides in operations such as scaling in/out or moving a user from one resource to another.

trans-unit.source: Subsequent operations can now use the cached resolution to access the constrained resource.
trans-unit.target: Subsequent operations can now use the cached resolution to access the constrained resource.

trans-unit.source: Since the actors support single-threaded execution, developers no longer need to worry about concurrent access to the resource.

trans-unit.source: Our scenario is as follows: we would like to process events using an actor called EventProcessor, which is responsible for processing and persisting the event, in this case to a .CSV file for simplicity.

trans-unit.source: That is why we chose a file-based example to illustrate this particular point—writing to a single file from multiple actors will raise concurrency issues.

trans-unit.source: To address the problem we introduce another actor called EventWriter that has exclusive ownership of the constrained resources.
